Award.AwardTitle: The Effects of Social Capital and Cultural Models on the Retention and Degree Attainment of Women and Minority Engineering Undergraduates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this study is to broaden understanding about how social capital and cultural models of engineering success (CMES) contribute to the retention and degree attainment of women and minority engineering undergraduates, traditionally under-represented in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). Social capital refers to the social connections of students and the resources available through those connections. CMES refer to beliefs about how to succeed in an engineering program (i.e. degree attainment.) The study builds from the premise that women and minority undergraduates who succeed in engineering programs are more likely to 1) enter with and acquire/develop various forms/levels of social capital and 2) resolve conflicts between their CMES and the culture espoused by the program.

The proposed four-year longitudinal study, which builds on a prior research project, is guided by social capital and cultural model theoretical frameworks. The study will employ a mixed methods approach, specifically a partially mixed concurrent dominant status design in which both quantitative (online surveys) and qualitative (face-to-face and video interviews) data are collected concurrently. The data will be gathered from engineering students at eleven (11) diverse collaborating institutions (Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University, Florida International University, Florida State University, Mercer University, Michigan State University, Polytechnic University of Puerto Rico, University of Florida, University of Michigan, University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, and University of South Florida). The outcome variables are: 1) the decision of entering students at these 11 institutions to pursue undergraduate engineering degrees and 2) retention of these students to the fourth year of their engineering programs. The two-fold goal of the research is to: 1) identify the effects of social capital and CMES on the retention and degree attainment of women and students traditionally underrepresented in engineering and 2) examine the relationship between social capital and CMES. An innovative aspect of the study is the use of cognitive diagnostic assessment (an extension of item response theory) to measure CMES. The results from the research project will make theoretical contributions in engineering education and is likely to transform cultures in engineering departments and facilitate the design of interventions that would broaden the participation of women and minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
According to NSF, women and African Americans, Latinos, and American Indians/Alaskan Natives are underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). They are often subjected to overt sexism, racism, discrimination, stereotyping, and isolation. In response to this hostile climate, students in undergraduate STEM programs often switch to non-STEM majors before graduation. In this study, using anthropological and sociological theoretical frameworks, we examined how social capital and culture models impact the persistence of women and underrepresented minority (URM) engineering undergraduates. Social capital refers to the social connections of students and the resources available through those connections. Cultural models refer to beliefs about how to succeed in an engineering program (i.e., time management, teamwork, joining professional engineering organizations).

Our study tracked a cohort of first-year engineering undergraduates over five years. These students were recruited from diverse universities including seven predominantly White institutions (PWIs), one historically Black college and university (HBCU), and three Hispanic-serving institutions (HSIs). We developed and administered five surveys annually to these students. The first survey inquired about respondents? experiences while in high school. Surveys 2 to 5 asked respondents the same questions about their experiences in their engineering programs in the previous year. Surveys 2 to 5 were sent to students who completed the survey in the previous year and indicated that they had not switched to non-engineering majors or had graduated. The sample for the first survey was 2186, second survey 1754, third survey 1240, fourth survey 1109 and fifth survey 906. We interviewed 55 women and URMs who responded the first survey in their second year and conducted follow up interviews with 36 of them in the fourth year.

 We found that men have slightly higher persistence rates from the first survey to the second survey and the second survey to the third survey, but women have a higher persistence from the fourth to fifth survey. Asian students have the second highest persistence rate, followed by White students, and then Latino students. Overall, students who acquired more social capital were more likely to persist than those who acquired less social capital. Black/African American students have the overall lowest persistence rate, but those with higher levels of social capital when they entered their program were more likely to persist than those who had lower levels of social capital when they entered. We found that URMs who participated in professional engineering organizations and other engineering related activities were more likely to persist to the second year than URMs who did not. Overall, the social capital that students acquired prepared them for and helped them to mitigate challenges that they experienced.

Regardless of their persistence, women and URM students changed their cultural beliefs about how to be successful in engineering from the first to the second interview. In the second interview, they explained that when they entered their engineering programs, they believed that they only had to study hard and get good grades to be successful, but now they believed that it was important to acquire social capital to be a successful engineering student. They specifically mentioned the importance of participating in study groups, obtaining internships, conducting research, forming supportive relationships with their peers, and participating in professional engineering organizations such as the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE), the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE), and the Society of Women Engineers (SWE). However, Blacks/African American students shared that they often experienced racism not only in their engineering programs, but on the wider university campus. Some Blacks/African American students reported that they felt that their academic abilities and engineering skills were denigrated because of others? perceptions of their race/ethnicity. Women reported microaggressions from their male peers and professors, such as commenting on their appearance or perceived ability, denying them the opportunity to use power tools, or expecting them to do less technical aspects of group work. We also found that the social capital students acquire while enrolled in the program provided the insights needed to mitigate potential challenges.

Findings from this study have implications for diversity efforts of universities across the nation. Our results suggest that engineering programs should encourage students, and in particular URMs, to participate in professional engineering organizations in their first year because participation is such organizations provides the social capital needed to boost their academic and social integration, thereby increasing their persistence. However, we contend that this strategy will only be successful if engineering programs also transform their culture which traditionally views the first (and sometimes second) year as the ?weed out? period. This callous ?weed out? culture is particularly harmful to women and URMs.
